data.title: Brunswick High grad Jason Yachanin stars in 'Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead'
data.meta_description: Courtesy of John EwingAn actor from "Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead" mugs for the camera. Brunswick native Jason Yachanin will be forever known to fans of Troma's ultra-cheap cult films as Arbie, slayer of chicken zombies. Yachanin, who grew...
data.text:
Brunswick native Jason Yachanin will be forever known to fans of Troma's ultra-cheap cult films as Arbie, slayer of chicken zombies.

Yachanin, who grew up in Brunswick, and Troma Entertainment ringmaster Lloyd Kaufman, will introduce "Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead" next week at Cleveland Institute of Art Cinematheque.

Kaufman will introduce the film Friday, Oct. 3, and Saturday, Oct. 4; Yachanin will be here Saturday only.

The Cinematheque, usually home for highbrow fare, is stepping on the wild side with this offering.

"It's a very campy horror comedy, also a musical," Yachanin said by phone from New York recently.

Yachanin, 27, plays loser-geek Arbie, whose girlfriend Wendy (Kate Graham) goes to college and comes out as a lesbian. Wendy and her girlfriend join a group of ultra-PC activists picketing against a fast-food joint that's built on top of a sacred grave. Arbie, out for revenge against Wendy, gets a job at the restaurant. When angry spirits turn customers into chicken zombies, Arbie and his co-workers have to defend the restaurant and destroy the zombies.

Entertainment Weekly's Owen Gleiberman calls it "a soft-core scatological zombie kitsch musical." The movie marks Troma's return to the big screen after sending many movies straight to video.

Yachanin had never heard of Troma Entertainment -- known for raunchy fare like "The Toxic Avenger" series, "Terror Firmer" and "Redneck Zombies" -- before he saw the audition listing in a New York newspaper. It said Troma was looking for a nerdy-geeky guy.

"I kinda fit that type," he admitted.

The movie was shot over two months in 2005 in Buffalo, and premiered in May in New York.

The shoot was like a demented summer camp. One house for the cast and crew. One shower. One rule: Actors got the shower first. Yachanin remembers standing under a freezing shower to wash off fake blood and vomit.

"That day I was the dirtiest I've ever been," he said. "You're primed for anything after that."

Troma founder Lloyd Kaufman directed, co-wrote and acted in "Poultrygeist." Kaufman was nice to the actors but screamed at the crew, Yachanin said. Many were die-hard Troma fans who traveled from Europe and Australia for a chance to be on the receiving end of a Kaufman tirade.

Yachanin said he plans to join Kaufman at Cinema Wasteland Movie and Memorabilia Expo, Friday-Sunday, Oct. 3-5 at the Holiday Inn Select, 15471 Royalton Road, Strongsville (www.cinemawasteland.com). Kaufman will be there three days; Yachanin will appear Oct. 4 only.

Yachanin graduated from Brunswick High School in 1999. He moved to New York after his 2003 graduation from Baldwin-Wallace College.

"Poultrygeist" was Yachanin's first film. Since then, he's done theater and commercials, and appeared on "Saturday Night Live."

The Troma name may not open doors, but it's definitely an attention-getter on his acting resume.

"People do know Troma," he said.
